message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pruritic rash on face and scalp and greasy yellow scales suggest Seborrheic dermatitis, which is commonly seen in patients with HIV. Allergic contact dermatitis and Pityriasis versicolor do not present with greasy yellow scales. Pellagra presents with a malar rash and photosensitivity, which are not seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of using new shaving cream and the location of the rash near the hairline and eyelids suggest Seborrheic dermatitis. Pellagra is caused by niacin deficiency and would manifest with diarrhea and other symptoms. Pityriasis versicolor presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules. Allergic contact dermatitis would manifest with acute pruritic rash and blisters. The patient's HIV status and alcohol use may also contribute to the development of Seborrheic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash, location, and greasy yellow scales at eyelid margins suggest seborrheic dermatitis, which is common in patients with HIV. Allergic contact dermatitis has a more acute presentation, while Pellagra and Pityriasis versicolor do not typically present with rash in the locations described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of using a new shaving cream and the appearance of greasy yellow scales at the margins of the eyelids suggest seborrheic dermatitis. Allergic contact dermatitis is usually more widespread, and pellagra and pityriasis versicolor do not typically present with this type of rash. The patient's HIV and alcohol use may also contribute to the development of seborrheic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the rash, its location, and the presence of greasy yellow scales at the margins of the eyelids suggest the most likely diagnosis is Seborrheic dermatitis. Allergic contact dermatitis can also cause a rash, but it is usually a more widespread rash and not just in certain areas. Pellagra and Pityriasis versicolor are less likely given the patient’s history and rash presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the rash on the face and scalp, as well as the presence of greasy yellow scales on the eyelids, strongly suggest Seborrheic dermatitis. Pellagra usually presents with a photosensitive rash, while Pityriasis versicolor presents with hypopigmented macules rather than inflammatory papules and plaques. Allergic contact dermatitis usually presents with an acute onset of intensely pruritic, erythematous vesicles and bullae.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a pruritic rash on the face and scalp with greasy yellow scales, which is characteristic of seborrheic dermatitis. Contact dermatitis would usually affect the site of contact, while pellagra and pityriasis versicolor do not typically present with these symptoms. The patient's HIV status and alcohol use may contribute to seborrheic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of using a new shaving cream and the presence of greasy yellow scales at the margins of the eyelids suggest seborrheic dermatitis. Allergic contact dermatitis would result in a more diffuse rash, while pellagra and pityriasis versicolor are less likely given the patient’s history and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the location of the rash and the greasy yellow scales, suggest a diagnosis of seborrheic dermatitis. Allergic contact dermatitis would present with more of a reaction, and pellagra and pityriasis versicolor generally present differently. The patient's HIV status and use of antiretroviral therapy may also contribute to the development of seborrheic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the rash is pruritic and located on the scalp and face, along with the presence of greasy yellow scales at the margins of the eyelids, suggests the most likely diagnosis is Seborrheic dermatitis. The patient’s use of a new shaving cream may have triggered the condition, and his HIV and alcohol use may have contributed to its development. Allergic contact dermatitis would likely show a more acute onset after exposure to a known allergen, while Pityriasis versicolor typically presents with hypopigmented patches. Pellagra typically presents with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, and is not associated with greasy yellow scales.
